properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall of 20 cm expected today and a further 20 cm on Saturday. A series of Pacific frontal systems will move across the region for the next few days and give periods of snow heavy at times. Snowfall amounts of near 20 cm are expected for each 24 hour period beginning today. The snow should ease early next week. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #YTStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-05T06:02:24-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-04T14:03:24-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3279352265.2020
Area: South Klondike Highway - Carcross to White Pass
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rainfall amounts near 50 mm expected. A slow moving front over the area will cause rain to intensify this morning over Kitimat. Rain will taper off overnight in Kitimat as the front moves northward but will begin in Stewart this evening. Rain will persist most of Saturday in Stewart. Kitimat can expect about 30 mm of rain today and 20 mm tonight. Stewart will receive about 20 mm tonight and a further 30 mm on Saturday. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-05T04:43:36-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-04T12:44:36-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0758499686.2020
Area: North Coast - inland including Kitimat, North Coast - inland including Stewart
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rainfall amounts near 60 mm expected Friday and Friday night. A slow moving front over the area will cause rain to intensify Friday morning and continue most of Friday night. About 30 mm of rain is expected to fall on Friday and a further 30 mm Friday night before easing in the early morning hours of Saturday. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-04T20:27:12-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-04T04:28:12-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0398041027.2020
Area: North Coast - inland including Kitimat
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, is expected. The ground, already near saturation, has little ability to absorb further rainfall. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.

properties.Summary:
Description: Strong easterly winds will whip up the snow and produce blizzard conditions today. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory in effect for today. Heavy snow currently occurring along and north of Highway 407 may be causing reduced visibilities. This reduction in visibility together with snow quickly accumulating on roads could potentially lead to hazardous driving conditions. The snow should taper to scattered flurries in the afternoon. Areas closer to the lakeshore where the precipitation is a mix of snow and rain are not expected to be affected. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-04T23:45:52-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-04T14:50:52-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0616422819.2020
Area: Pickering - Oshawa - Southern Durham Region
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall Sunday night to Monday night. Locations: Eagle River, Cartwright to Black Tickle, Norman Bay to Lodge Bay, Red Bay to L'Anse-au-Clair. Maximum snowfall: Possibly exceeding 30 cm, especially inland. Remarks: Areas immediately along the coast from L'Anse-au-Clair to Mary's Harbour may see precipitation fall as rain or wet snow, significantly reducing accumulations. If precipitation falls only as rain, accumulations could reach 30 mm instead. Location: Upper Lake Melville. Maximum snowfall: Possibly reaching 15 cm. Remarks: Depending on the track of the low, the Upper Lake Melville area may or may not see significant snowfall. Confidence for this area is lower. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-12-05T11:39:25-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-04T19:40:25-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1075807046.2020
Area: Red Bay to L'Anse-au-Clair, Norman Bay to Lodge Bay, Cartwright to Black Tickle, Upper Lake Melville, Eagle River
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with gusty winds and visibility frequently near zero in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. Very strong winds, with the potential for gusts to 100 km/h this today, will maintain blizzard conditions for today and tonight. Blizzard conditions will end Saturday morning as winds start to diminish. ### Travel is expected to be extremely hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-05T08:24:05-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-04T17:22:05-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1972693071.2020
Area: Resolute
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall expected beginning Saturday evening. Total snowfall: 20 to 30 cm. Locations: central and northern New Brunswick. Time span: Saturday through Monday morning. Remarks: Snow and strong winds are expected to spread across parts of New Brunswick late on Saturday. There is still a fair amount of uncertainty on the exact track of this developing low pressure system. The snow may change briefly over to ice pellets or freezing rain over central parts of the province. Snowfall warnings may be issued as this system draws nearer. Conditions will improve on Monday. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-05T06:50:32-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-04T14:51:32-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1423893416.2020

properties.Title: Les Suêtes Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Maximum Les Suetes gusts: 90 km/h. Time span: Overnight Saturday until early Sunday morning. Remarks: Strong southeast winds will develop Saturday evening with gusts to 90 km/h overnight until early Sunday morning. ### Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Les Suêtes wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-05T11:54:20-00:00

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant rainfall is expected on already saturated ground. Total rainfall: 40 to 60 mm. Locally higher amounts possible. Locations: southern New Brunswick. Time span: Saturday evening until Monday morning. Remarks: Rain is expected to begin Saturday and may become heavy, at times, over some areas overnight. There is still some uncertainty with the exact track of this developing low pressure system. Rain may become mixed at times with snow near Fredericton. Strong northeasterlies will also accompany the precipitation this weekend. Rainfall warnings may be issued on Friday afternoon. The rain will taper off by Monday. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-05T06:50:40-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-04T14:51:40-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2427377517.2020

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: An intense low pressure system will develop over the Eastern U.S. Seaboard on Saturday. It will affect Central Quebec beginning Saturday evening, then reach Eastern Quebec on Sunday. This storm may bring significant snowfall amounts, strong winds, widespread blowing snow, and even freezing rain. Although it is still too early to forecast with certainty how much snow will fall and what areas will be hardest hit, the Lower St. Lawrence and the Gaspé Peninsula could see up to 30 centimetres of snow. Freezing rain should mainly affect the Eastern Gaspé Peninsula. These poor weather conditions may have a significant impact on travel. Be prepared for changing road conditions that could deteriorate rapidly in heavy snow and blowing snow. Future weather statements will provide more details as the low pressure system's track as well as precipitation types and amounts become more certain. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-05T09:55:07-00:00
